text:
I also think you will need to start from scratch, which has the benefit that you get to do it right. A tool might categorize posts the wrong way, miss it when posts belong in multiple categories, etc.
The hard part with these kinds of things I find is keeping them going and clean once the initial set is made and new content is added on.

elements.text:

text:
I'd make sure you consistently use the same spelling across all of your content and that you tailor that spelling to who your main target audience is.

When writing in English, you're almost certain to attract visitors from different countries. The question is which of those you mostly want to sell to :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Hi all - this question is kind of broad but I work in a niche B2B space (our target audience is tech partnerships, product managers and engineers who work on SaaS product integrations) and I am capable of finding the relevant keywords for search but I'm wondering what my options would be in terms of getting a bump on our SEO through an agency or freelancer. Most of our target keywords are low volume because this is a niche space. I'm trying to figure out what an agency or freelancer could do for us given it is a highly specialized space - would they mainly be getting us quality backlinks (can an agency do that well in such a focused space)?

Basically just wondering if anyone has experience with SEO in a niche B2B tech space and could advise whether there is an agency or freelancer that could significantly improve our SEO (assuming I already have the keywords) and if so about how much would that cost?

We are a small company, have a lot of content but no one focused on SEO specifically (beyond having reviewed the keywords and searches occurring) and I am trying to figure out if this would be worth investing in or if our limited budget is better spent elsewhere.

text:
Have something very similar at the moment. Trying to optimise with pillars around the low volume keywords out there and digging around for any backlinks at the same time.

From the reading that I have been doing, it seems that most agencies will probably focus on boosting your domain authority with backlinks first. If you already have decent DA, I reckon they will focus on building the content pillars.

Ready to stand corrected. Hope this is of some help!

text: In regards to the content itself, a specialized freelancer or agency could check whether you're targeting the best keywords for each piece of content and if each article is optimized as best as it could be. Finding the keywords to target is one thing, optimizing for them is another. Are you already ranking well for the keywords you're targeting?

elements.text: In regards to the content itself, a specialized freelancer or agency could check whether you're targeting the best keywords for each piece of content and if each article is optimized as best as it could be. text: <@U02J7DM81AQ> Thanks! We rank well for some of the keywords but not others. We have 11 (excluding our brand name) in the top 10. I believe the articles are optimized at a base level, and I'm not sure the incremental optimization (if there is some) would have a significant impact. Would love to hear from anyone who saw solid results off of that level of change. I'm sure it is tough to evaluate in the abstract but would love to hear from anyone in niche B2B tech space who has done this and would recommend.

text:
I would take a step back and check over the keyword research and not assume it is wrapped up.


For your current content check the intent of the article fits to the cluster of keywords it is going for.

I think in some of these newer spaces you can introduce ideas and new perspectives to the search results too.

text:
Thanks <@U01NW9AE6CV> - very nice of you to do this! I completely agree with your approach but the problem for me is all the problems and related searches identified to my particular buyer are low search volume.

For example, I would like to attract product managers who oversee SaaS product integrations. Any search related to their particular role is low volume.

As product managers, they have pain points that are broader and I could write content that attracts "b2b SaaS product managers" but 99% of that audience would be irrelevant to me (as 99% SaaS product managers are not handling product integrations) and it would be very competitive to get traffic there because there is a ton of quality content for PMs already.

So I have "integration user stories" which brings in like 40-50 clicks a month from search but is probably 90% the right person and it is not that competitive because not that many people are writing on it.

But I could certainly try to experiment more with higher volume, less targeted searches and see if I am able to get enough clicks to attract some of the relevant audience.

Thank you!

elements.text: Thanks

- very nice of you to do this! I completely agree with your approach but the problem for me is all the problems and related searches identified to my particular buyer are low search volume.

For example, I would like to attract product managers who oversee SaaS product integrations. Any search related to their particular role is low volume.

As product managers, they have pain points that are broader and I could write content that attracts "b2b SaaS product managers" but 99% of that audience would be irrelevant to me (as 99% SaaS product managers are not handling product integrations) and it would be very competitive to get traffic there because there is a ton of quality content for PMs already.

So I have "integration user stories" which brings in like 40-50 clicks a month from search but is probably 90% the right person and it is not that competitive because not that many people are writing on it.

But I could certainly try to experiment more with higher volume, less targeted searches and see if I am able to get enough clicks to attract some of the relevant audience.

Thank you!
